facts.text: Appeal from the High Court of Judicature at Bombay, Civil Appeal No. XXVI of 1949, from judgment dated 20th March 1947 by Stone C.J. and Coyajee J. in Appeal No. 42 of 1946.

anchor.surface_text: APPEAL from the High Court of Judicature at Bombay. Civil Appeal No. XXVI of 1949. This was an appeal from a judgment and decree of the Bombay High Court  Stone C.J. and Coyajee J.  dated 20th March, 1947, in Appeal No. 42 of 1946, reversing a judgment of Chagla J. dismissing an application.

facts.text: Chagla J. dismissed respondent's application under Indian Arbitration Act 1940 on 2nd July 1946.

anchor.surface_text: The matter was dealt with by Mr. Justice Chagla who overruled the contentions of the Respondent and dismissed the application on 2nd July 1946.

facts.text: Bombay High Court Division Bench (Stone C.J. and Coyajee J.) reversed Chagla J., set aside dismissal, declared arbitration agreement invalid and set aside award.

anchor.surface_text: reversing a judgment of Chagla J. dismissing an application. made by the respond- ent under the Indian Arbitration Act, 1940, praying inter alia that the arbitration agreement companytained in certain companytract numberes sent by the appellants to the respondent be declared invalid and void and for setting aside an award made by arbitrators appointed under the said companytract numbere.

facts.text: Appellants are members of East India Cotton Association Ltd., respondent is not a member.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellants were and are members of the East India Cotton Association Ltd. The Respondent, however, was number and is number a member of that Association.

facts.text: In April 1945, respondent employed appellants as agents to effect forward contracts for sale/purchase of cotton per Association rules.

anchor.surface_text: In April, 1945, the Respondent employed the Appellants as his agents to effect forward companytracts for the sale and or purchase of companyton according to the rules, regulations and bye-laws of that Association.

facts.text: Between 9th April 1945 and 10th August 1945, appellants as agents executed various contracts for July and September 1945 cotton deliveries and sent contract notes.

anchor.surface_text: Between the 9th April, 1945, and the 10th August, 1945, the Appellants as such agents put through various companytracts for sale and or purchase of companyton for July, 1945, and September, 1945, deliveries and sent to the Respondent companytract numberes in respect of each of such companytracts.

facts.text: On 10th August 1945, outstanding purchase of 900 bales cotton at Rs.432 per candy for September 1945 delivery.

anchor.surface_text: On the 10th August, 1945, the purchase of 900 bales of companyton at Rs. 432 per candy for September 1945 delivery remained outstanding.

facts.text: Respondent claims instructed appellants on 11th August 1945 to close outstanding purchase by selling 900 bales at not less than Rs.426 per candy.

anchor.surface_text: According to the Respondent, on the 11th August, 1945, the Respondent instructed the Appellants to close the said outstanding purchase by selling 900 bales for September 1945 delivery at a rate number less than Rs. 426 per candy, which is said to be the prevailing market rate on that date.

facts.text: Appellants deny receiving any instruction from respondent on 11th August 1945 to close the contract.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellants, however, deny that any instruction was given by the Respond- ent on the 11th August, 1945, for closing the outstanding companytract. They deny the receipt of the Respondents letter of that date.

facts.text: On 18th August 1945, respondent put instructions on record and asked for contract note.

anchor.surface_text: As the Respondent did number receive any companytract numbere from the Appellants in respect of the closing transac- tion of 900 bales, the Respondent on the 18th August, 1945, put on record his aforesaid instructions and asked the Appellants to send the companytract numbere.

facts.text: 21st August 1945 was a clearing date, sum of Rs.18,900 due from respondent to appellants.

anchor.surface_text: According to the Appellants the 21st August, 1945, was a clearing date and on that clearing a sum of Rs. 18,900 became due and payable by the Respondent to the Appellants

facts.text: Appellants' letter dated 22nd August 1945 repudiated respondent's allegations, demanded Rs.18,900 by 23rd August, threatened to square up at discretion.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellants by their letter of the 22nd August, 1945, repudiated the allegations in the Respondents last men- tioned letter and called upon the Respondent to pay up Rs. 18,900 and gave numberice to him that if he failed to pay up the amount by numbern of the 23rd August, 1945, the Appellants would be companypelled to square up the outstanding companytract at their discretion on account and at the risk of the Respond- ent.

facts.text: Respondent on 24th August 1945 denied fabricating story, repudiated liability for Rs.18,900, returned bill.

anchor.surface_text: The Respondent on the 24th August, 1945, denied having fabricated any false story and repudiated liability for Rs. 18,900 and returned the Appellants bill.

facts.text: On 27th August 1945, appellants closed outstanding contract by selling 900 bales at Rs.356 per candy, sent contract note No.17996.

anchor.surface_text: On the 27th August, 1945, the Appellants closed the outstanding companytract for purchase of 900 bales by selling the same at Rs. 356 per candy for September 1945 delivery and along with their letter dated the 27th August, 1945, sent companytract numbere No. 17996.

facts.text: Respondent's letter 28th August 1945 reiterated prior instruction, denied new instruction, returned contract note No.17996.

anchor.surface_text: The Respondent by his letter dated the 28th August, 1945, reit- erated the story of previous instruction for closing the companytract, denied having given any instruction to the Appel- lants to close the companytract on the 27th August, 1945, and returned the companytract numbere No. 17996.

facts.text: On 28th August 1945, appellants wrote claiming Rs.34,313 and desired reference to arbitration per contract notes.

anchor.surface_text: On the 28th August, 1945, the Appellants wrote to the Respondent claiming Rs. 34,313 and expressing the desire to refer the disputes to arbitration in terms of the arbitration agreement companytained in the companytract numberes.

facts.text: Arbitrators appointed by both parties, entered reference, fixed meeting on 24th October 1945.

anchor.surface_text: Both parties appointed their respec- tive arbitrators. The arbitrators entered upon the refer- ence and eventually fixed the 24th October, 1945, for a meeting of the arbitrators.

facts.text: Respondent alleges received notice of arbitration meeting on 22nd October 1945, could not attend due to Income Tax appearance, sent agent for adjournment.

anchor.surface_text: The Respondent alleges that he received the numberice of meeting only on 22nd October, 1945, and companyld number attend the meeting on the 24th October, 1945, as he had to appear before the Income Tax Officer on the same day. Accordingly, the Respondent sent his agent to attend the arbitration meeting and to obtain an adjournment.

facts.text: Arbitrators rejected adjournment, made ex parte award on 24th October 1945 for Rs.34,313 plus interest and costs.

anchor.surface_text: The arbitrators, however, rejected the application for adjournment and made an ex parte award on the same day for Rs. 34,313 and interest and companyts.

facts.text: Respondent filed appeal to Board of Association on 10th November 1945.

anchor.surface_text: Being aggrieved by the award the Respondent on the 10th November, 1945, filed an appeal to the Board of the Association.

facts.text: Pending appeal, respondent discovered contract notes not in official form, void under Bombay Cotton Contracts Act IV of 1932.

anchor.surface_text: The Respondents allegation is that pending the said appeal he discovered that the companytract numberes rendered by the Appellants from time to time including the companytract numbere No. 17996 were number in accordance with the prescribed official form of companytract numberes of the Association and he was advised that in the premises the companytracts were void under the provisions of the Bombay Cotton Contracts Act  IV of 1932

facts.text: Respondent made application to High Court under Indian Arbitration Act to declare arbitration agreement invalid and set aside award.

anchor.surface_text: praying inter alia that the arbitration agreement companytained in certain companytract numberes including companytract numbere No. 17996 sent by the Appellants to the Respondent be declared to be invalid, void and unenforceable and be set aside and that a purported award made by the arbitrators appointed in terms of the said companytract numberes be set aside.

facts.text: Contract notes sent by appellants lacked updated deposit clause (Rs.25 instead of Rs.12.5 per bale) and omitted two clauses for bye-law 65-A.

anchor.surface_text: A companyparison of the two forms of the companytract numberes will reveal the following differences - In the companytract numbere rendered by the Appellants to the Respondent the last sentence providing for deposit at the end of the margin clause is missing. ... The two new clauses required to be inserted in the company- tract referred to above have also been omitted.

facts.text: East India Cotton Association is a recognised cotton association under Bombay Cotton Contracts Act 1932.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdispute that the East India Cotton Associa- tion is one of the recognised companyton associations for the purposes of the said Act.

facts.text: Bye-law 51-A amended during war, minimum deposit reduced to Rs.12-8-0 per bale, notified 19th September 1945.

anchor.surface_text: During the war bye-law 51-A was amended by reducing the minimum amount of deposit from Rs. 25 per bale to Rs. 12-8-0 per bale and accordingly the Government of Bombay by a Notification made on the 19th September, 1945,...

facts.text: Supreme Court agrees with Bombay High Court appellate decision, holds contracts void under Section 8 Bombay Cotton Contracts Act 1932 due to non-conformity with bye-laws.

anchor.surface_text: We find ourselves in agreement with the decision of the appellate Court.

issues.text: Whether Section 8 of the Bombay Cotton Contracts Act, 1932 avoids contracts only if they are not made subject to the bye-laws or also if the contract notes rendered are not in the prescribed form as required by bye-law 82

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge was of the opinion that section 8 of the Bombay Cotton Contracts Act, 1932, only avoided the contracts i.n case of contravention of the first require- ment, namely, if the contracts were not made subject to the bye-laws, but had no concern with the contravention of the second requirement, namely, if the contract notes were not in the prescribed form.

issues.text: Whether, when a contract is reduced to writing, the writing is the repository of the contract and if not in accordance with the bye-laws, the contract is void under Section 8

anchor.surface_text: Ordinarily, when a contract between the parties is reduced to writing, the writing becomes the repository of the contract and that writing only can be looked at to ascertain what the contract between the parties is, and if that writing is not in accordance with the bye- laws, the contract itself must be void.

issues.text: Whether the pre-existing oral contract was in accordance with the bye-laws even if the subsequent contract note was not

anchor.surface_text: We do not, however, feel pressed to emphasize this aspect of the matter, for, assuming that there was a pre-existing oral contract between the parties dehors the written contract note, as held by Chagla J. we have yet to see whether the so-called pre- existing oral contract was in accordance with the bye-laws, for if it were not, then it would be hit by section 8

issues.text: Whether the rubber stamp provision stipulating deposit at a rate not less than Rs. 25 per bale is in accordance with the amended bye-law 51-A requiring not less than Rs. 12-1/2 per bale

anchor.surface_text: The respondent contends that this term is not in accordance with the bye-laws of the Association. The Appellants on the other hand contend that there is no discrepancy, because a provision for a rate not less than Rs. 25 per bale does not contravene or is not inconsistent with the provision for a rate not less than Rs. 121/2 per bale.

issues.text: Whether mere subjection of the contract to the bye-laws incorporates the specific provisions of bye-law 65-A despite omission of the required clauses from the contract note

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the Respondent has been and is that by reason of the omission of the two clauses at the end of the contract note actually issued by the Appellants it was not in accordance with the bye-laws. The learned Attorney-General appearing for the Appellants contends that the contract was expressly made subject to the bye-laws and, therefore, the provisions of the new bye-law 65-A were by reference incorporated in the contract.

issues.text: Whether the arbitration agreement contained in the contract notes is invalid, void and unenforceable and the award made thereunder is to be set aside

anchor.surface_text: made by the respond- ent under the Indian Arbitration Act, 1940, praying inter alia that the arbitration agreement contained in certain contract notes including contract note No. 17996 sent by the Appellants to the Respondent be declared to be invalid, void and unenforceable and be set aside and that a purported award made by the arbitrators appointed in terms of the said contract notes be set aside.

arguments.claim: Contract notes not in accordance with bye-laws due to missing last sentence in margin clause, incorrect rubber stamp deposit rate, and omission of two clauses for bye-law 65-A, rendering contracts void under Section 8 Bombay Cotton Contracts Act, arbitration agreement invalid, and award set aside

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the respondent was that the contract notes actually issued were not in accordance with the bye- laws of the Association and were accordingly void under Section 8 of the Bombay Cotton Contracts Act, 1932, and that, that being so, the arbitration agreement incorporated in the contract note was also void and there could be no reference to arbitration and there could be no award as purported to have been made by the arbitrators on a refer- ence under the void contracts.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge pointed out that whereas bye-law 80 required that delivery contrac- ts must be made on the official form and that the hedge contrac- ts, when made in writing, must be made in the form given in the Appendix, clause 82 did number require that the contrac- ts between members acting as commission agents on the one hand and their constituents on the other must be in writing or in particular form.

arguments.claim: Rubber stamp deposit clause imposes higher minimum than bye-law 51-A allows and misrepresents amended provision

anchor.surface_text: The rubber stamp provision clearly imposes on the respondent as the constitu- ent the liability to deposit a higher amount as the minimum amount to be deposited and is to that extent not in accord- ance with bye-law 51-A. Apart from this consideration there is another serious objection to the rubber stamp provision.

arguments.claim: Omission of bye-law 65-A clauses renders contract note not in accordance with bye-laws as incorporation by reference insufficient for agent-constituent contracts

anchor.surface_text: This contention, we are satisfied, is unsound. Bye-law 65-A in terms regulates the relationship between members and incorporation thereof in a contract between a member agent and an outsider constituent will make no sense and on a plain reading will be meaningless.

holdings.text: We find ourselves in agreement with the decision of the appellate Court.

anchor.surface_text: We find ourselves in agreement with the decision of the appellate Court. Ordinarily, when a contract between the parties is reduced to writing, the writing becomes the repository of the contract and that writing only can be looked at to ascertain what the contract between the parties is,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supreme Court concurs with Bombay High Court Division Bench that reversed single judge and held contracts void, arbitration agreement invalid, and award set aside.

holdings.text: Ordinarily, when a contract between the parties is reduced to writing, the writing becomes the repository of the contract and that writing only can be looked at to ascertain what the contract between the parties is, and if that writing is not in accordance with the bye-laws, the contract itself must be void.

anchor.surface_text: Ordinarily, when a contract between the parties is reduced to writing, the writing becomes the repository of the contract and that writing only can be looked at to ascertain what the contract between the parties is, and if that writing is not in accordance with the bye- laws,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Written document is exclusive evidence of contract terms; non-compliance with bye-laws in writing voids the contract under Section 8.

holdings.text: assuming that there was a pre-existing oral contract between the parties dehors the written contract note, as held by Chagla J. we have yet to see whether the so-called pre-existing oral contract was in accordance with the bye-laws, for if it were not, then it would be hit by section 8 of the Bombay Cotton Contracts Act, 1932.

anchor.surface_text: We do not, however, feel pressed to emphasize this aspect of the matter, for, assuming that there was a pre-existing oral contract between the parties dehors the written contract note, as held by Chagla J. we have yet to see whether the so-called pre- existing oral contract was in accordance with the bye-laws,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pre-existing oral contract terms identical to non-compliant written note; must independently satisfy bye-laws or void under Section 8.

holdings.text: The rubber stamp provision clearly imposes on the respondent as the constituent the liability to deposit a higher amount as the minimum amount to be deposited and is to that extent not in accordance with bye-law 51-A.

anchor.surface_text: The rubber stamp provision clearly imposes on the respondent as the constituent the liability to deposit a higher amount as the minimum amount to be deposited and is to that extent not in accordance with bye-law 51-A. Apart from this consideration there is another serious objection to the rubber stamp provision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Higher minimum deposit rate (Rs.25 vs Rs.12.5) inconsistent with amended bye-law 51-A; terms of business cannot override bye-laws.

holdings.text: the rubber stamp provision wrongly summarises and sets out the provisions of bye-law 51-A and consequently is not in accordance with that bye-law.

anchor.surface_text: The language of that rubber stamp provision clearly indicates that it purports to summarise and set out what is payable under bye-law 51-A. ... Therefore, the rubber stamp provision wrongly summarises and sets out the provisions of bye-law 51-A and consequently is not in accordance with that bye-law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rubber stamp inaccurately states amended bye-law 51-A provision (Rs.25 instead of Rs.12.5), rendering it non-compliant.

holdings.text: This contention, we are satisfied, is unsound. Bye-law 65-A in terms regulates the relationship between members and incorporation thereof in a contract between a member agent and an outsider constituent will make no sense and on a plain reading will be meaningless.

anchor.surface_text: This contention, we are satisfied, is unsound. Bye-law 65-A in terms regulates the relationship between members and incorporation thereof in a contract between a member agent and an outsider constituent will make no sense and on a plain reading will be meaningless. Further, under bye-law 65-A the last buyer has certain options.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bye-law 65-A inter-member only; reference insufficient without explicit clauses in agent-constituent contract note; meaningless otherwise.

holdings.text: section 8 of the Bombay Cotton Contracts Act, 1932, only avoided the contracts in case of contravention of the first requirement... but had no concern with the contravention of the second requirement... [rejected by agreement with appellate court]

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge was of the opinion that section 8 of the Bombay Cotton Contracts Act, 1932, only avoided the contracts i.n case of contravention of the first require- ment, namely, if the contracts were not made subject to the bye-laws, but had no concern with the contravention of the second requirement, namely, if the contract notes were not in the prescribed form.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects single judge view; non-conforming contract notes void contracts under s8 as writing is repository and must comply fully with bye-law 82.

anchor.surface_text: This contention, we are satisfied, is unsound. Bye-law 65-A in terms regulates the relationship between members and incorporation thereof in a contract between a member agent and an outsider constituent will make no sense and on a plain reading will be meaningless. Further, under bye-law 65-A the last buyer has certain options.
We find ourselves in agreement with the decision of the appellate Court.
